segments.text: your research on your own yeah okay now i i now have some questions i'd like to ask you concerning research on your own and that is attitudes towards it uh how much of your how much of your meteorological work applied to physical oceanography and vice versa did you immediately feel a kinship between the atmosphere and the ocean
Yes.

Actually, the equations were all developed by the same school of oceanography meteorologists in Scandinavia, so that all you had to do was change a sign here or there, and you studied exactly the same equations of motion.
All I had to do was think upside down when I went into oceanography, and I had most of the theory.
Now, most of the emphasis in your early work, at least on the first couple of papers I looked at,
were in the area of applied sciences.
Your first paper on wave data and your second one, of course, was on the application of VT and the pouring of underwater concrete.
Did you always have this direction towards applied sciences when you began?
Or was this the direction Scripps took you?
Well, one of the jobs I had at Scripps, aside from the VT section, was in forecasting sea and swell.
And I did that for quite a while.
And that was just a natural outcome of that.
The bridge engineers were building this bridge about four or five miles from our laboratory, and they were having trouble with concrete setting.
And they wanted to know what in the world was wrong.
And somehow, they hadn't been taught that the freezing point of seawater is below zero degrees centigrade.
And if you have fresh water in your concrete, it'll freeze and spoil.
So we said, all you have to do is put your BT down.
You can tell what the temperature is and know when to pour.
It was just an accident.
So in both those cases, these things were just sort of natural evolutions of what you were working on in and around scripts.
This is right.
And did you work with Walter Munk there, by the way?
I took classes with Walter, but I didn't work with him.
Whenever I think of wave forecasting and so forth, I think of the work that the script was working on there.
This is right.
Actually, I did the wave forecasting under the direction of Sverdup himself.
Oh, okay.
And Sverdup worked with Munk in developing some of the improved techniques for forecasting.
Mm-hmm.
How did you miss Operation Crossroads, by the way?
I don't know.
Everybody I know went but me.
I kept looking for your name on Operation Crossroads.
I don't know.
I've wondered about that all my life.
I thought maybe I had already deduced that this had begun your interest in wave work before I got your Vita.
Now...
When you begin to deal with seawater, you know, as you move into your next series of papers, what led you there?
Well, I don't know what papers we're talking about.
I'm talking about your work with electro conductance of seawater.
Well, I really perhaps should not have been listed as a co-author on these.
I did not do a great deal of work.
Okay.
I think that that...
I might better not have had my name on some of those papers.
Okay, well, certain things I could see.
Measuring upper level wind from a small ship, for example.
That seemed to fit in the kind of category that I would have expected you to work in.
Well, I started off with light, and my first main papers were all in light.
Right.
And then I came to Oregon State, and I had to get into some sort of oceanography, and the natural thing was to get into estuaries.
So I have a number of papers on estuaries.
Then I have some papers on intensity and frequency of storms and wave forecasting in the mid-Pacific.
And this came about because I was a witness in a very large court case for the loss of a ship.
Oh, really?
And these were just direct outcomes of the results of the research work that I did for this court case.
This was the loss of the Pennsylvania, which was lost with all hands in 1954.
How?
Tell me about it.
Just an extremely bad storm.
They had something like 18 hours of waves over 20, 30 feet high, and it was just too much for the Soul Liberty ship, and it cracked in half, and that was the end of it.
How would they call you in as a witness?
Well, the ship was carrying a fairly expensive cargo vessel,
for the Korean War.
It was under charter to the U.S. And this cargo was lost, and it was insured both by the owners of the cargo and the owner of the ship.
So the court case was to determine whether there was negligence on the part of the ship owner.
And the lawyers for the ship owner felt that the bad weather should be classed as an act of God.
If it's an act of God, then it's nobody's fault.
Well, it turns out that
The whole precedent in English law is that no storm, aside from a tropical hurricane, is an act of God.
And this is the way it came out, and the owners lost.
But what the lawyers were trying to do was build a case that this was one of the worst storms that had ever come up.
And one outcome of that was the story, can mid-latitude storms be as severe as tropical typhoons and hurricanes?
And I think in this paper in the U.S.
Naval Institute Proceedings, I proved beyond a question of a doubt that there is bad or worse.
Yeah.
and yet ships are expected to go through those.
Okay.
I mean, I was looking at my list of your papers here, and this has got to be the one in 58, I suppose.
Right.
Well, but almost all the papers in 55 and 56 really are on light scattering and light effects.
This is right, and this was sort of the ending of my thesis period.
Okay.
That's what I wanted to know.
Right.
I made a couple of trips on script ships after I got here and wrote,
couple papers there, or one paper, Selective Transmission of Light in Tropical Pacific Waters.
But then I turned over and the next batch are all on coastal oceanography.
Absolutely.
The next thing that you apply are really on estuary work with some work on water temperatures.
I noticed you've done one on disposal of low-level radioactive waste in the Pacific coastal waters.
This was a committee report, a committee by John Isaacs
headed by John Isaacs, and we worked out, tried to come up with a solution for the problem, and I don't know whatever happened to the report because you never hear it referenced or anything.
Okay, well, that was why I was so interested.
I'd never heard of it before, and it just all of a sudden came at once and sort of appeared, particularly since your work in coastal waters around here.
Well, I was on this National Academy committee for two or three years while this was being written.
Are you optimistic about the disposal of nuclear waste and what have you in the ocean?
Personally, I think it's perhaps the only solution in the long run, but most people won't agree with me.
I think that the oceans are big enough that if it's properly diluted that we can get rid of some of it.
If we don't get rid of it in the water mass itself, then I think we can bury it in sediments.
The idea of burying it on land just horrifies me.
You're pumping it down into aquifers.
So I take it from that, and with all the work you've done along the coastal zone, is that possibly you don't consider the ocean in such a danger of pollution as one might be led to believe.
Well, I'm sure that it's badly polluted near large ports and near large sewer outfalls.
But I think the open ocean, aside from certain persistent chemicals used in agriculture, I think it has a tremendous ability or resiliency to pollution.
Okay.
I certainly don't want to put words in your mouth, but do you see the oceans then as an extension of man's life on Earth?
That is, is that their primary purpose?
No.
Okay.
I think that as we get more and more people on land and as our natural resources are depleted, we're just going to have to move out into the oceans to get more and more material.
With your work on estuaries and what have you, are you optimistic about mariculture or aquaculture?
I think it's strictly a matter of cost.
As things get more and more expensive, we'll do more and more of these things.
This is showing up in Japan.
They have a lot of aquaculture going on there.
It's just a matter of cost, what we're willing to pay and what we can pay.
What about mining from the sea, as long as I have you on that topic?
I think it's inevitable that we're going to begin mining more and more.
The nodules will be first, and eventually we're going to have hard rock mining.
I don't see any other solution.
So you do see, then, us turning more and more to the sea, I suppose, for both food and mining materials.
Well, in 1957, during the IGY, oceans just all of a sudden received all kinds of funding
partially because the ocean was going to feed the teeming millions.
That idea seems to have fallen into some disregard.
I think the idea of feeding the teeming millions perhaps is not as good as it should be.
I don't really think there's that much material present.
If we're willing to lower the trophic levels and can eat plankton in some way, then I think we can feed many more people
I think of aquaculture or mariculture as being a source of crabs and oysters and delicacies that are high-priced things.
Okay, then you see it more as gourmet food, if I may say that.
Gourmet food, right.
What about you guys doing some work up and down?
Well, not you guys, because that's wrong, but the marine fisheries are doing work up and down the coast with ranching and salmon, for example.
I think this is a fine idea, but salmon is certainly a gourmet luxury.
It's $3.80 a pound in the market.
You don't see for dropping to a dollar a nickel a pound like hamburger meat or anything.
No, sir.
Okay, unfortunately.
I was afraid you were going to answer that way.
No.
All right, now, when I have, after you, working in predictive water temperatures, you know, beginning in 64, it's only Oregon and Coast.
I might talk a little bit about predictive water temperatures if you don't mind.
Okay, sure.
I want you to talk about what you want to talk about.
In about 1956 or 57, I was still getting only $10,000 a year from ONR, and I couldn't expand in any way.
So I talked the Fish and Wildlife Service into a contract, I think it was for $10,000, to predict water temperatures in reservoirs.
And this had been done rudimentarily by several people in the past, but I developed a system.
under this contract.
And then I went on to have a private consulting firm called Water Research Associates.

And over a period of 10 years, I made 30 studies of dams and reservoirs from Alaska to Southern California for all sorts of agencies and predicted before the dams were built what the temperature structure would be downstream.
And this is a combination of oceanography, meteorology, and limnology.
Limnology, right.
Now, this is much broader than I'd anticipate.
I had some questions on... Straightened two sets of teeth, took my family to Europe, put all three kids through college.
Oh, that's excellent.
That's excellent.
I had several questions about temperature that I had jotted down here, but I want to know something else differently now that you're talking that way.
Limnology.
How did you become interested in it?
Did you just see the potential for measuring these temperatures?

Well, I was casting about for something to do to make myself somewhat indispensable at Oregon State, and they didn't have any courses in physical limnology, so I started teaching physical limnology, and this is how I started.
Okay, and did you find it extremely difficult to make any transfer?
Did it seem to fit in well already with your work of atmosphere and ocean?
I think it was a natural transfer.
There was no problem.
Actually, the few reservoirs that were built, it turned out the forecasts were reasonably good, and everybody seemed to be quite happy with them.
Do you still do this?
No.
After I had the system going, and business was pretty good, two or three engineering firms set up their own system and copied my forecasts and took it away from me.
They were working full-time on it, so that was the end of it.
No part-time work.
Then after that, what do you move into?

Well, I began to do, when I started research again, I cast about for a subject that wasn't being covered that I thought might be important, and it turns out that air-sea interaction was becoming very important at that time, and it was concentrated really on two scales, and one scale was what you might call the meter scale, micrometeorology over the oceans, and there was a lot of work done on that, and then it jumped to
synoptic scale, several thousand kilometers, and there was very little mesoscale work being done.
So I thought, well, I'll study mesoscale meteorology over the oceans, and this is what I've been working in since.
And what sort of work have you been doing?
Well, there have been a number of large-scale international air-sea interaction studies, and I have taken part in

several of these and have studied the mesoscale primarily the mesoscale distribution of winds over the ocean surface variability organization in the variability these studies have been the jason british jason expedition in 1972 the german john swap expedition in the north sea in 1973
The Japanese Amtech study in 75, and this September I'll take part in the British Jason 77, the next year Jason 78.
In 79 I hope to take part in a Somali current study.
So that each time I join these large organizations, simply to get the logistic support and to be able to furnish data which other people need.
One of the most interesting studies has to do with mesoscale organized confections.
If you get a high enough air-sea interaction difference, you'll find that there are cells formed which are the order of 30 to 50 kilometers across, which act almost identical to large cumulus clouds.
And during the AMTEC study, I set up some buoys between Korea and Okinawa and measured the characteristics of these cells as they moved across the buoy array.

I could tell where the air was coming down, where it was colder and drier, coming around the edges of the cells, how it warmed up underneath the cells as the water passed over the warm ocean waters, and so on.
Now, are you working with satellites?
No, I use satellites photos because they'll tell you, you can look at them and see these individual cells and get their size and how they change.

It seemed to me for a while, and partially because of the work that was going on in terms of waves, wave currents, that for physical oceanography, satellites and buoys were the wave of the future, if I may use that pun.
That this was what was going to redo physical oceanography, which is going to make physical oceanography again sort of the Enfield it had once been but was no longer.
Well, I think everybody felt this was true.
But the buoys have not really panned out.

We've taken a sort of a jump toward, well, the popular thing now, aside from satellites, are various and sundry towed instruments, or free fall instruments, that give you an in situ measurement of currents, salinity, temperature.
And there are all kinds of these fish that are towed.
do all sorts of high-speed physical oceanography that seems to be the wave of the future right now.
What kind of data do you get from those?
Well...

Most of them have concentrated on fine structure in the currents, and in fine structure in temperature, fine structure in salinity, various and sundry types of waves, internal waves that occur in the oceans, identifying them, measuring their scale, speed, and so on.
Now, I noticed in 1967, weather and solar radiation.
that a paper on, was this leading towards this, your work on solar radiation, was this leading towards production of energy?
No.
No, okay.
No, I'm just interested, it's a source of heat that goes into the oceans, which then is given back to run the atmosphere.
Okay, so still, best I can tell you that the second one, incoming solar radiation, dealt with light, is that?
Where are we now?
On 68, incoming solar radiation right here over the tropical ocean?
in nature.
That seemed to me like that was dealing with light rather than, you know.
No, this is heat.
And heat, okay.
Our sole interest was heat.
Then that would fit in nicely then with the rest of the things you're doing, which involves heat on down through 69 and so forth.
Right.
Okay.
All right.
I just wanted to make sure that you hadn't slipped the paper in on me that I didn't recognize along the way.
No.
On these international voyages, how cooperative were the other international oceanographers?
Well, I
In almost every case, I've found that they're extremely cooperative.
They appreciate the assistance that you're able to give them, and they give you assistance in turn.

For example, I had been having trouble getting a ship to use in 1968 for the British Jason expedition, and the Germans came on and volunteered six days of ship duty, ship time, without cost if I needed it.
It turns out that I will use the Woods Hole ship instead.
All right.
I hate to ask you to make invidious comparisons, but what would you say about oceanography in other countries as compared to oceanography in our own?
Are there any countries who are particularly ahead of us in the science of oceanography, behind us?
I think as far as sheer volume is concerned that the Russians are considerably ahead of us.
But their quality appears, from what I can see, to be spotty.
They have some extremely fine theoreticians, they have some good practical people, but in general they have a lot of pedestrian work done too.
Any comments on anyone else you'd like to?
Well, I think the quality of research in England and Germany, particularly Germany, is very high but they do not have very extensive programs compared to the U.S.
I've worked with the Germans considerably and I find them very sharp people and just as good as any we have in this country.
But you think it's just a matter of volume in those cases?
I think it's more a matter of volume.
I want to return to your work here in a second, but I want to ask you one more question here.
Do you see with current international restrictions developing,
As an oceanographer, your work being pushed back closer and closer all the time to the shore?
I think this can happen, and I'm hoping it won't happen.
And I know that a number of laboratories in this country are working feverishly to sort of clear the way in the future to work with various countries by bending over backwards trying to help them.
And I think this is about the only way we're going to do it.
If we're a source of help and encouragement,
to a less developed country, I think we'll be more welcome than if we're arrogant.
Okay, so you think it is going to be possible as a scientist, perhaps, to work with the 200 mile limits?
Well, we have to work with them.
Yeah, that's true.
Oregon State, we're not the only school that's done this, but I followed what we've done.
About 10 years ago, I started cooperative work with various West Coast South American countries.
We visit them whenever we can.
have encouraged their students to come.
We've tailored the coursework to their background rather than to a standard background.
We have 15 Latinos enrolled at the present time, which is more, I think, than anybody else in the country.
We concentrate on Mexico down to Chile.
We've sent people down to Chile to teach.
Several people have gone there.
We've done cooperative work aboard Mexican ships.
two large cooperative studies with the Mexican Navy.
My new student in the fall will be from Costa Rica.
We already have one from Costa Rica.
So that we really have bent over backwards to develop the Western tier, because this is where we want to work in the future.
And I think it's good for both sides.
I had no idea you'd done all that.
When did you make a decision deliberately to recruit students?
About 10 years ago.
About 10 years ago.
Was it sort of accidental?
Did you think you need contacts in that country or you just?
Well, I was fortunate and got a prize, $1,000.
And my wife in a weak moment said I could do what I wanted with it.
Oh, okay.

So I was going to meet a script ship, I think it was in Panama, and I just took a month off and spent my $1,000 traveling all over all the labs in South America and got acquainted with people and set the groundwork.
Okay, good.
What did you get the prize for?
Pardon?
What did the prize come for?
Distinguished professor thing, something.
Okay, here at Oregon State?
Yeah.
Oh, that's excellent, excellent.
Now, in terms of just surveying your research, we'd only really got until about 1969, okay?
What would you like to mention in this period and through here of particular significant accomplishments, you think?
Oh, goodness.
Well, I worked with Bill Quinn on a number of things.
He was the primary investigator, and I had a lot of rap sessions with him.
And there was some, I think, fairly important work came out of this.
Now, Bill Quinn has changed from working on the heat budget of the tropics to the prediction of El Nino.
And I've not done any of that work with him.
It was about that time then that I began to do more and more air-sea interaction work.
OK.
In 1972, I changed over full time to research the NRC interaction.
I have one other thing to ask before we get to 1972.
A conference on the interaction of sea and atmosphere, is that the move that makes the change for you?
About 1971, as I said before, I cast about, where was there a hole?
There was a hole, and that's how I got started.
Now that conference, that was just a report on a meeting, the first big air-sea interaction meeting that the American Meteorological Society set up.
And incidentally, I got up after having the flu to go, I was chairman of one of the sessions, and
I shouldn't have gone, came back and had a heart attack.
Oh, good.
I just wore myself down.
I shouldn't have gone to that meeting.
And that was five years ago then?
Yeah.
That was right after that conference.
Okay.
And, well, it didn't seem to slow your research down very much.
You seemed to have recovered marvelously.
I've been very fortunate.
And so in the last several years, we're in effect involved in
and interaction between oceans and seas.
What sort of work have you done there that you think of particular significance?
What's been the most important thing?
What have you looked for?
Well, I've found evidence of organized convection, evidence of roll vortices.
Two papers have been published with clear evidence of roll vortices.
This evidence is in the surface wind field.
It shows an alternating of directions as these vortices move past a buoy.
Then, for the first time, I've reported on the near-surface change in meteorological parameters and oceanographic parameters, which are associated with open and closed mesoscale convection cells.
One interesting thing that's not of great importance, but I found evidence of a turd-ironal tide in winds, which hadn't been reported before.
I've shown that over relatively short distances, wind statistics over the ocean can vary considerably, and that was not known.
The usual thing is to take a weather ship and extrapolate a thousand miles all around it.
You just can't do this.
meteorological driving forces are subject to major changes in time and space that need to be studied if you're going to study any part of the RCNR action process.
As a matter of fact, your work has continued on through 1977, doing these same kinds of things.
Is that the direction you think your work will take you in the future?
I think this is all I'm going to do from here on out.
You think you're going to look at this large-scale interaction and the rest of the way through?
Mesoscale interaction.
I'm sorry, mesoscale interaction.
This is miles to maybe 100 miles or kilometers to 100 kilometers in time from minutes to a week.
Okay.
And out of curiosity, do you think weather prediction will come out of this?
I think that, aside from resources in the sea, that the best opportunity for benefiting mankind that oceanographers and meteorologists have is in weather forecasting.
And in order to do this, we have to understand air-sea interaction processes much, much better than we do at the present time.
And this is one of the reasons we're working.
How far away are you from long-range weather forecasting?
Well, there are two ways of looking at that.
One of the most pressing things is to improve our forecasting, say, from a four-day forecast to a five- or six- or seven-day forecast.
We've been on
A lot of people have been working on this, and no one seems to have come through with any breakthroughs.
We're just sort of stuck on a roughly four-day forecast.

But as far as long-period trends are concerned, six months in advance or a year in advance, I think the work of Nimaeus and a number of other people indicates clearly that we're going to be able to forecast trends a little better than we could before.
But the most important, well, that's important in itself.
But improving our weather forecasting by two days would make a tremendous economical impact on the country.
Routing of fuels, electrical network management, all of these things depend on how weather changes around the country.
And if we could do it in six or eight days, it would just be wonderful.
But I'm not sure we can.
And that's what we're all working on.
And that's where your work is pressing presently.
I think so.
